title: 108_s1633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Notification and Credit Restoration Act of 2003". Congress finds that the privacy and financial security of individuals are increasingly at risk due to the widespread collection of personal information by both the private and public sector. Credit card transactions, real estate records, consumer surveys, credit reports, and Internet websites are all sources of personal information for identity thieves. Identity theft is one of the fastest-growing crimes in the United States and has become a major law enforcement challenge in the new economy. Identity theft is a fast-growing crime in the United States, posing a major challenge for law enforcement. Criminals steal personal information to commit financial crimes like opening fraudulent credit card accounts and writing bad checks. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported identity theft to the Federal authorities. Identity theft is costly to consumers and the US marketplace. Victims often have to contact multiple law enforcement agencies, credit reporting agencies, and creditors over many years due to each fraud event. Victims of identity theft must contact various law enforcement agencies, credit reporting agencies, and creditors over many years. The government and financial institutions share the responsibility to protect consumer information and assist victims of identity theft. The private sector has a shared responsibility to protect consumers' sensitive personal information from identity theft, assist victims, and implement fraud prevention measures such as customer notification and credit report access. SEC. 3. TIMELY NOTIFICATION OF UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO PERSONAL INFORMATION. Amendment to the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act requires notification to customers of unauthorized access to personal information. In this section, a breach is defined as the unauthorized acquisition of data compromising the security of personal information held by a financial institution, excluding good faith acquisitions by employees for business purposes. The term "personal information" for a customer of a financial institution includes the first name or initial, last name, and certain data elements like social security number or driver's license number, when not encrypted. The notification requirement for a breach of personal information includes social security numbers, driver's license numbers, credit card information, and access codes for financial accounts. The financial institution must notify customers affected by a breach of personal information promptly. This includes access to financial account information and notifying consumer reporting agencies. The financial institution must notify customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement agencies in case of a breach affecting a large number of customers. The financial institution must promptly notify customers and law enforcement of any breach affecting a large number of customers, as required by regulations. Any entity holding personal information for a financial institution must also inform the institution of any suspected breaches without delay. The financial institution must promptly notify customers and law enforcement of any breach affecting a large number of customers. Notification of the breach or suspected breach should be made promptly upon discovery, considering the legitimate needs of law enforcement and measures necessary to determine the scope of the breach. Notification of a breach may be delayed for law enforcement purposes if it would impede a criminal investigation. Once law enforcement determines it won't compromise the investigation, notification must be promptly made. Notification can be provided in various forms. Notification of a breach may be delayed if it would impede a criminal investigation, and must be promptly made once law enforcement determines it won't compromise the investigation. Notification can be provided in writing or electronically. The notification of a breach can be delayed if it hinders a criminal investigation and must be promptly made once law enforcement deems it safe. Notification can be in writing or electronically, consistent with electronic records and signatures regulations. If the number of affected customers or notification costs are prohibitive, alternative forms of notification may be used. In cases where a breach or suspected breach hinders other forms of notification, a financial institution can use alternative methods such as email notices or conspicuous postings. The financial institution can notify affected customers through email, website postings, or media in case of a breach compromising customer information security. Notification of a breach of personal information compromising customer data security can be done through media, email, website postings, or other forms as prescribed by the Federal Trade Commission. Notifications may also be sent to consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies as per FTC rules. Each notification to a customer regarding a breach of personal information must include a statement informing them that credit reporting agencies have been notified and that a fraud alert will be placed on their credit report. The customer's credit report will have a fraud alert to notify creditors of a breach, requiring customer authorization for new credit issuance. Compliance with this section is required for financial institutions. Financial institutions must comply with the standards set by the appropriate regulatory body for information security. They are deemed compliant if they have a comprehensive security program and notify customers and credit agencies of breaches according to their internal policies. Financial institutions must have a comprehensive security program in place to comply with information security standards. They must notify customers and credit agencies of breaches according to their internal policies. Customers can seek damages through civil action for violations of this section. Financial institutions must comply with information security standards and notify customers of breaches. Customers can seek damages through civil action for violations of this section, with the option of injunctions for financial institutions in violation. The rights and remedies under this section are in addition to those available under applicable law. Compliance with this section is required. The rights and remedies available under this section are in addition to any other rights and remedies available under applicable law. Compliance with this section by a financial institution does not violate any laws prohibiting the disclosure of financial information. Financial institutions are not required to disclose information unless specifically provided for in this section. The section allows financial institutions to disclose information to third parties, with limitations to comply with existing laws. It does not impose new recordkeeping obligations on financial institutions. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF FRAUD ALERTS IN CONSUMER CREDIT REPORTS. Section 605 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a definition of fraud alerts as a statement in a consumer's file indicating potential identity theft. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in a consumer's file to prevent identity theft and unauthorized credit issuance. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in a consumer's file to prevent identity theft. Consumer reporting agencies must obtain express preauthorization from the consumer through designated phone numbers or other reasonable means of communication. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in a consumer's file to prevent identity theft. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert in the consumer's file promptly upon notification by a financial institution or upon the consumer's request. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act requires consumer reporting agencies to include a fraud alert in a consumer's file upon the consumer's request and with appropriate evidence of identity theft. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert in a consumer's file upon request, supported by evidence of identity theft. The agency is also responsible for informing anyone accessing the consumer's credit information about the presence of a fraud alert, regardless of the type of report requested. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for the duration and removal of fraud alerts in consumer credit files, ensuring consistency across all reporting agencies. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for the duration and removal of fraud alerts in consumer credit files, ensuring consistency across all reporting agencies. Violations include failure to notify users of a fraud alert in a consumer credit report. The regulations require reporting agencies to notify users of fraud alerts in consumer credit reports. Users who fail to comply with preauthorization procedures and issue credit to someone other than the consumer are also in violation. No adverse actions can be taken based solely on fraud. The regulations prohibit issuing credit to someone other than the consumer and taking adverse actions based solely on fraud alerts in consumer credit reports. Access to credit reports and scores is addressed in Section 5 of the regulations. No Fee in Certain Cases - Section 612(c) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with no-cost access to credit reports and scores. Consumers can request these disclosures once a year and every 3 months during a 1-year period after a fraud alert is placed on their file. The Fair Credit Reporting Act allows consumers to access credit reports and scores at no cost once a year and every 3 months after a fraud alert is placed. Credit reporting agencies can charge a reasonable fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act now requires financial institutions to provide notification to the credit reporting agency for fraud alerts, as mandated by the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. Additionally, credit scores must be included in credit reports as per the amendment to Section 609(a)(1) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the Federal Trade Commission, in consultation with other financial regulatory agencies, must issue final regulations to implement the Act's amendments.
